channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: In digital age, recall beauty of paper
item.description: Bob Greene says as even as we embrace the wonders of online media in a digital age, it's worth appreciating the tactile, comforting, here-when-you-want-me world of words and pictures on paper

item.title: Lingering effect of war on Iraqis
item.description: CNN's Arwa Damon looks at the psychological impact of the last decade on the Iraqi population.

item.title: Sandberg: Speak up, believe in yourself
item.description: Sheryl Sandberg says institutional barriers hold women back, but they can improve the odds of success by believing in themselves and taking action

item.title: Why consumers are fleeing the media
item.description: Howard Kurtz says financial pressures are prompting news outlets to cut back on reporting, and audiences are tuning out

item.title: Bono: Fight to end extreme poverty
item.description: Bono says if the current trajectory can hold, extreme poverty could be eliminated by 2030

item.title: Sudan judges taught to amputate?
item.description: Sudan's Deputy Chief Justice recently made the alarming announcement that his government might start training judges to cut off the hands and legs of convicted criminals, if doctors refuse to carry out amputations as punishment.

item.title: Why Mars water revelation is big deal
item.description: An announcement on Tuesday marked, quite literally, a watershed moment in the history of solar system exploration. NASA scientists said an analysis of drilled rock samples collected by the Curiosity rover shows that ancient Mars could have supported living microbes.

item.title: After two years of war, Syrian first lady visits opera
item.description: The wife of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad makes a rare public appearance. Photos show her smiling, and surrounded by children and young women.

item.title: Getting to know Syria's first family
item.description: Syrian President Bashar al-Assad is the face of his country's regime, but his family members are also believed to wield a powerful influence on issues facing the country.

item.title: Asma al-Assad stands by her man
item.description: In her Vogue photograph she is beautiful, wrapped in a luxurious fuchsia pashmina. She's very rich, as the story repeatedly conveys, a stern mother of three, a woman who tries to make it happen everyday while, of course, teetering in her beloved Christian Louboutin heels.

item.title: Terrorism vs. revolution in Syria
item.description: CNN's Ivan Watson reports on the civil war in Syria that has pitted rebel groups against each other and their government.

item.title: Losing a generation of children
item.description: CNN's Nick Paton Walsh reports on the effect two years of war is having on the children of Syria.

item.title: Inmates caught after helicopter escape
item.description: Canadian police have arrested the fourth and final suspect from a dramatic, airborne prison escape.

item.title: Helicopter pilot forced to cooperate
item.description: Canadian police have arrested three people involved in a daring helicopter escape from a Quebec prison. CBC reports

item.title: Francis meets Argentine president
item.description: The Vatican seeks to quell controversy over Pope Francis' conduct in Argentina's "Dirty War," amid claims he failed to protect two kidnapped Jesuit priests.

item.title: Pope's past divides Argentina
item.description: CNN's Shasta Darlington reports from Buenos Aires on the dark period in Argentine history, when thousands disappeared.

item.title: Mugabe arrives for pope's inaugural
item.description: Robert Mugabe, Zimbabwe's controversial president, is under a European Union travel ban, but he arrived in Italy for the inauguration of Pope Francis on Monday.

item.title: U.S. tourist killing suspect fled to Syria
item.description: Turkish authorities have brought the chief suspect in the murder of an American woman slain in Turkey to Istanbul after he was apprehended at a border crossing between Turkey and Syria on Sunday.

item.title: India: 6 held over tourist gang-rape
item.description: Six men are in custody after a Swiss tourist was allegedly gang-raped while camping in central India. The rape of a New Delhi woman sparked outrage in December.

item.title: Guilty pleas in rape of Swiss woman
item.description: Five men have confessed to gang-raping a Swiss tourist in India.

item.title: U.S. lawmaker questions Kim's 'stability'
item.description: A U.S. congressman expresses concern about the "stability" of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un after months of provocative statements and refusal to negotiate its nuclear program.

item.title: Prominent cleric to Saudis: Clean up act
item.description: One of Saudi Arabia's most prominent and popular clerics has issued a stark warning to the Saudi government, saying it must take serious steps toward instituting reform, stamping out corruption and releasing political detainees "before violence is kindled"

item.title: Political corruption alleged in Spain
item.description: A Spanish lawyer and former member of parliament speaks out about political party financing. CNN's Al Goodman reports.

item.title: HSBC to cut thousands more jobs
item.description: HSBC is gearing up for thousands more job cuts, with Europe's biggest bank by market value set to outline the next stage in its strategic overhaul at an investor day in two months' time.

item.title: Japan tops Asian IPO chart
item.description: Companies have raised more cash in Tokyo this year than in Asia's other developed markets put together, taking Japan to the top of the region's IPO charts.

item.title: 2 killed in Indiana plane crash
item.description: At least two people were killed and three others injured Sunday when a small plane crashed in South Bend, Indiana, a police captain said.

item.title: Egyptian police protest beard ban
item.description: Dozens of police officers stage a sit-in to protest the government's ban on police beards. CNN's Reza Sayah reports.

item.title: 'Roach-fest' horror on Greyhound bus
item.description: Roaches crawling out of air vents. Roaches climbing up seats and windows. Roaches on people's coats and hats. Roaches everywhere.

item.title: Wingsuit-wearing daredevils in Rio
item.description: CNN's John Vause talks to one of two daredevils who wore wingsuits during an unsanctioned jump over Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Murray won't testify in Jackson trial
item.description: Dr. Conrad Murray, who was Michael Jackson's personal physician, is refusing to testify in the wrongful death lawsuit that the singer's mother filed against concert promoter AEG Live.

item.title: Tennis: Nadal - now better than ever?
item.description: Look out Novak Djokovic, Roger Federer and Andy Murray, Rafael Nadal is back -- and the numbers stacking up suggest he's better than ever.

item.title: More court drama awaits Lindsay Lohan
item.description: The soap opera that is Lindsay Lohan offers more drama after the actress missed a Sunday night flight to Los Angeles where she goes on trial Monday morning.

item.title: Quest: Deposit tax punishes Cypriots
item.description: Never underestimate the capacity of the Eurozone to shoot itself in both feet

item.title: Cypriots bear brunt of bailout
item.description: Cyprus faces a tough challenge trying to enforce a controversial levy. CNN's Isa Soares reports.

item.title: Why is Cyprus in crisis?
item.description: CNN's Elinda Labropoulou on the evolving cash crisis on the island of Cyprus.

item.title: Tracking huge great white shark
item.description: Here's a view from aboard a fishing boat of what it's like to nab and tag a great white shark for research purposes.

item.title: Becker: Ronaldo the tennis ace?
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo has the perfect physique for tennis, according to tennis great Boris Becker.

item.title: 'Miniature TV' in your tummy
item.description: PillCam is a ingestible video camera with a transmitter which lets doctors look inside your digestive tract.

item.title: The man behind 'Lara Croft'
item.description: Ian Livingstone is a legend in the fantasy games world. In 1995, he stumbled upon "Lara Croft" and the rest is history.

item.title: Rodman: Kim Jong Un 'my friend'
item.description: Ato Boldon, Politico's Ben Smith and Reihan Salam discuss criticism over Dennis Rodman's trip to North Korea.

item.title: Marcel Desailly's Ghana regret
item.description: French World Cup winning defender Marcel Desailly tells CNN that he would have loved to play for Ghana at least once.

item.title: 'Batman' helps UK police
item.description: A costumed crusader brought in a man wanted for burglary.

item.title: Go inside a sinkhole
item.description: Ever wonder what a sinkhole looks like on the inside? CNN's David Mattingly dives in for a peek in Florida.

item.title: Why media's failure on Iraq still stings
item.description: The 10th anniversary this month of the invasion of Iraq will remind most people of a divisive and dubious war that toppled Saddam Hussein but claimed the lives of nearly 4,500 Americans and more than 100,000 Iraqi civilians.

item.title: New pope makes a buzz with Catholics
item.description: CNN's Ben Wedeman looks at how the personable character of Pope Francis is energizing Catholics around the world.

item.title: 5 epic helicopter prison escapes
item.description: The spectacular, airborne escape of two Canadian inmates Sunday stunned witnesses and showcased the illicit ingenuity behind one of the more creative prison breaks.

item.title: Envoy: Obama has strong ties to Israel
item.description: Michael Oren says the president's trip to Israel, his first while in office, will demonstrate the strength of the connections between the two nations

item.title: U.S. death: Singapore firm accused
item.description: A police investigation into one man's death has now become an issue between two countries.

item.title: Sudan amputation sentences slammed
item.description: Sudan's Deputy Chief Justice recently made the alarming announcement that his government might start training judges to cut off the hands and legs of convicted criminals, if doctors refuse to carry out amputations as punishment.

item.title: First days show pope's humility
item.description: One expert says Jorge Bergoglio has already shown that as Pope Francis he will be the down-to-earth man people yearn for in a spiritual leader.

item.title: Sandberg: Speak up, believe in yourself
item.description: Sheryl Sandberg says institutional barriers hold women back, but they can improve the odds of success by believing in themselves and taking action

item.title: Bono: Exit rock star, enter 'factivist'
item.description: Bono says if the current trajectory can hold, extreme poverty could be eliminated by 2030

item.title: Earliest ever cherry blossoms in Tokyo
item.description: Japan's prettiest national pastime of hanami, or cherry blossom viewing, has got off to its earliest start ever.

item.title: How I stood up to al Qaeda in war
item.description: CNN's Arwa Damon revisits Mohammed, a man who stood up to al Qaeda during the Iraq war.

item.title: Fairy tale of Swedish princess
item.description: A Swedish princess is laid to rest after living a fairy tale love story. CNN's Max Foster reports.

item.title: In digital age, recall beauty of paper
item.description: Bob Greene says as even as we embrace the wonders of online media in a digital age, it's worth appreciating the tactile, comforting, here-when-you-want-me world of words and pictures on paper

item.title: 300 days with Cirque du Soleil
item.description: On the road for 300 days a year, a Cirque du Soleil touring troupe of 175 relies on the same precise planning for its travel arrangements as it does for its acrobatic moves and dare devil routines.

item.title: Tribe marries same-sex couple
item.description: Gene Barfield and his partner, Tim LaCroix, celebrated their 30th anniversary by getting married.

item.title: Pope Francis cracks up cardinals
item.description: "I hope you haven't made a mistake," Pope Francis told the cardinals at his celebratory dinner after he was chosen to lead the Catholic Church. He then urged the assembled hierarchy to nourish their bodies, and said with a grin, "May God forgive you for what you've done."

item.title: Man gets airport flash mob surprise
item.description: An Oklahoma City man received a surprise proposal from his girlfriend after a two-year mission trip.

item.title: One-handed violinist
item.description: Adrian Anantawan prefers to be judged for what people hear, not what they see. What they'd see is a one-handed violinist.

item.title: Why internet is a surveillance state
item.description: Bruce Schneier says our surveillance state is efficient beyond the wildest dreams of George Orwell, and consumers are given little chance to opt out

item.title: Mother, daughter -- top collaboration?
item.description: If your mother is one of the world's best-loved children's authors who has written more than 70 books and sold well in excess of 11.5 million copies, you might think about taking a different career path.

item.title: Africa sick with 'Western diseases'
item.description: Major pharmaceutical companies are increasingly looking to harness Africa's opportunity, lured by an emerging middle class across the continent's growing urban centers.

item.title: 'Miniature TV' in your tummy
item.description: PillCam is a ingestible video camera with a transmitter which lets doctors look inside your digestive tract.

item.title: Fans eye rare Beatles pics
item.description: The first solo exhibition in about 20 years of early photos of the Beatles taken by a British photographer who designed five of their UK album covers is on display in London.

item.title: The epic battle of a 'Forgotten War'
item.description: Sixty years ago, in the freezing mountains of North Korea, U.N. forces defied the odds by escaping hordes of Chinese troops. Why is Hollywood yet to tell the tale?

item.title: Football: Referees under siege
item.description: A Dutch volunteer linesman is beaten to death, a teenage Spanish referee is violently assaulted, and in Germany a match official is hospitalized.

item.title: Popemobiles from trucks to limos
item.description: One of the first questions many people ask when they start a new job is: what type of car will I get? CNN explores the evolution of the pope's ride.

item.title: The U.N. drone investigators
item.description: Saima Mohsin gets an exclusive interview with the UN investigator of drone strikes by U.S. and others in Pakistan.

item.title: Shipwreck survivor recalls drama
item.description: Quen Cultra, Leo Sherman and Joe Strykowski set off on a journey around the world aboard a homemade catamaran. But their journey ended in disaster when two powerful storms upended the ship.

item.title: Iraq war: Phantom WMD
item.description: Ten years after the start of the Iraq War, CNN's Nic Robertson looks at the WMD report used to justify the invasion.

item.title: Old friends talk about David Bowie
item.description: David Bowie's school pals talk about jamming with the superstar and a fight which made its mark on music history.

item.title: Conan: St. Patrick's Day on a budget
item.description: Conan O'Brien's team shares budget friendly St. Patrick's Day tips.

item.title: CNN FC: Are English clubs in crisis?
item.description: CNN Football Club welcome Gaizka Mendieta and Boris Becker to the show to talk about the week's Champion's League results.

item.title: 50 years ago: Quasars found
item.description: Breathtaking blossoms nearly the size of our solar system are strewn across the universe -- hundreds of thousands of them. Quasars are, at the same time, among the most fiery monsters.

item.title: What is 'March Madness' in U.S.?
item.description: Are you coming to the United States soon? Welcome to America -- or between now and the second Monday of April, "Welcome to March Madness."

item.title: Sudan judges to cut off limbs?
item.description: Sudan's Deputy Chief Justice recently made the alarming announcement that his government might start training judges to cut off the hands and legs of convicted criminals, if doctors refuse to carry out amputations as punishment.

item.title: Putin revives Stalin- era fitness tests
item.description: Erin Burnett tackles Vladimir Putin's plans to reintroduce Stalin-era fitness tests for young Russians in the essay.

item.title: What's been won in Syrian civil war?
item.description: It's two years since repressed voices called for freedom in Syria. What's been won and lost in the brutal civil war?

item.title: Black Death 'plague pit' find in London
item.description: Work on a new London rail link has turned up a grisly find that harks back seven centuries, to a time when Black Death stalked the medieval city.

item.title: Hands-off with new Samsung phone
item.description: It's when your smartphone reads your eyes and movements to perform basic functions without tapping the screen.

item.title: Fusion 'the perfect energy source'
item.description: Until recently, fears of peak oil and dependence on Middle Eastern suppliers were the key factors shaping our energy policy, pushing governments to scramble for fossil fuel alternatives. Then came shale gas, tar sands, and other unconventional sources. Industry found ways to affordably extract fuel for decades to come. So many are now imagining an end to the energy crisis. That's a dangerous mistake.

item.title: 'Sick man' Greece runs out of drugs
item.description: Greece owes pharma firms $2.6 billion, but it's chronically sick patients running low on life- saving drugs that pay the most.

item.title: Hong Kong hides huge stash of ivory
item.description: Hong Kong is fast becoming the Fort Knox of ivory.

item.title: Xi: China's new boss in a hurry
item.description: Conventional wisdom had it that Xi would be a weak leader because he had not been hand-picked by Deng Xiaoping. How wrong was that?

item.title: Leaders vow fairness, frugality
item.description: President Xi Jinping promised citizens his government will pursue the "Chinese dream," in a keynote speech as the National People's Congress came to a close on Sunday.

item.title: Blix: Iraq War was a terrible mistake
item.description: CNN exclusive: Hans Blix, the former lead weapons inspector in Iraq, recounts conversations he had with Tony Blair and Condoleezza Rice in the lead-up to the war -- and worries history could repeat itself.

item.title: Why women are less free after Iraq War
item.description: Iraqi women may have obtained some benefits on paper since the war began, the reality is that they have lost far more than they have gained since the first bombs dropped on Baghdad in 2003.

item.title: Iraq War: Courage amid the carnage
item.description: Ten years on, the war has left a heavy toll on Iraqis who had no say. CNN's Arwa Damon reports everything that every resident knew to be normal was crushed, tearing down the very fabric of society.

item.title: Did Iraq War make Arab Spring?
item.description: 10 years after the invasion of Iraq, Ed Husain explores whether the fall of Saddam Hussein inspired Arab revolutionaries across the region.

item.title: Hans Blix
item.description: CNN exclusive: Hans Blix, the former lead weapons inspector in Iraq, recounts conversations he had with Tony Blair and Condoleezza Rice in the lead-up to the war -- and worries history could repeat itself.

item.title: Epic copter escapes
item.description: The spectacular, airborne escape of two Canadian inmates Sunday stunned witnesses and showcased the illicit ingenuity behind one of the more creative prison breaks.

item.title: Hopes for pope
item.description: "I hope you haven't made a mistake," Pope Francis told the cardinals at his celebratory dinner after he was chosen to lead the Catholic Church. He then urged the assembled hierarchy to nourish their bodies, and said with a grin, "May God forgive you for what you've done."

item.title: Xi in a hurry
item.description: Xi Jinping has taken the center stage as China's undisputed paramount leader.

item.title: Mars water
item.description: An announcement on Tuesday marked, quite literally, a watershed moment in the history of solar system exploration. NASA scientists said an analysis of drilled rock samples collected by the Curiosity rover shows that ancient Mars could have supported living microbes.

item.title: Top drinking nations
item.description: St Patrick's Day is upon us again. Time for the drinking world to pull on an unamusing leprechaun hat and order pints of the black stuff in a fake Irish accent.

item.title: Hong Kong: Ivory's Fort Knox
item.description: Hong Kong is fast becoming the Fort Knox of ivory.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Philippines taps geothermal potential
item.description: Eco Solutions looks at how the Philippines is tapping into its geothermal potential.

item.title: Macau's motorcycles go electric
item.description: A Macau company's love for motorcycles is helping the planet at the same time. CNN's Andrew Stevens reports.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: Sri Lanka's mass elephant migration
item.description: Poachers have decimated elephant populations across Africa and parts of Asia, killing thousands of animals for their revered ivory.

item.title: Xi: China's new boss in a hurry
item.description: Xi Jinping has taken the center stage as China's undisputed paramount leader.

item.title: Li Keqiang named Chinese premier
item.description: Li Keqiang on Friday was named China's premier, the No. 2 position in the Chinese government, completing the once-a-decade transition of leadership in the world's most populous nation.

item.title: Chinese farm claims dead pigs
item.description: A Chinese farm admitted to dumping dead pigs into Huangpu River, which had about 6,000 bloated carcasses pulled from its water this week, state media reported.

item.title: Will China finally 'bite' North Korea?
item.description: North Korea, China's longtime ally, has vexed Beijing for years with its rocket launches, nuclear tests, kidnapping of Chinese fishermen and other erratic behavior. Yet, Beijing has run interference at the United Nations to temper punishments against Pyongyang, and has even helped Pyongyang circumvent sanctions.

item.title: Coca-Cola probed over mapping
item.description: The government of a remote province in western China says it is investigating Coca-Cola over allegations that it illegally mapped parts of the province, as China and the US engage in an escalating war of words over cyber espionage.

item.title: Inflation warning from central bank
item.description: China must be "on high alert" against inflation, central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan said on Wednesday, striking a hawkish tone at his most important news conference of the year.

item.title: Artist Ai Weiwei to release album
item.description: Dissident Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, whose artwork is shown in museums around the world, is taking a different direction with his latest project -- a heavy metal album.

item.title: World's biggest mall a 'ghost town'
item.description: They built it, but the shoppers didn't come.

item.title: Report: Chinese military hacking
item.description: The Chinese government is sponsoring cyber-espionage to attack top U.S. companies, according to Grady Summers, vice president of security firm Mandiant.
